Award.AwardTitle: An ALMA Reconnaissance of Distant Dying Stars
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support an observational program to learn about mass loss in the late stages of evolution of intermediate-mass stars, especially those in the asymptotic giant branch (AGB) phase of evolution. The project focuses on three main questions: (1) how each generation of stars returns nuclear-processed and unprocessed material to the interstellar medium; (2) how much dust is produced in the winds from cool, luminous giants; and (3) how mass loss depends on the chemical abundances of the parent stars. The first phases of observations will be conducted in the near-infrared, with later follow-up observations on the new Atacama Large Millimetre-submillimetre Array (ALMA).

The study of dying stars has many implications for stellar evolution, galactic astronomy, and nucleosynthesis. Undergraduate students will participate in all stages of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An ALMA Reconnaissance of Distant Dying Stars

We received NSF funding to study the final phases of stellar evolution, when stars become red giants and eject most of their mass.  We aimed to (1) investigate how these stars pulsate and how that drives the mass-loss process, and (2) use these pulsations to identify samples to observe with the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) to better quantify how much mass the stars are losing.

Nearly all of the elements heavier than hydrogen and helium in the Universe were formed in and ejected from successive generations of dying stars.  To better understand this process in the earlier Universe, we focused on stars with low heavy-element abundances, which can be found in globular clusters in our own Galaxy and in nearby dwarf galaxies like the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds (LMC and SMC).

To study stellar pulsations, we observed the globular clusters M5 and M15 repeatedly at the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope (CFHT) and Lowell Observatory.  In their final stages, stars pulsate with long periods, typically taking one to two years or longer to complete a single pulsation cycle.  We obtained optical photometry for both M5 and M15 with the CFHT in seven epochs spread over 25 months.  Figure 1 shows the resulting color-magnitude diagram for M5.  The red giants are the brightest (top) and reddest (right) stars in the diagram, and all stars are color-coded by their variability.  For the most evolved red giants, the variability grows quickly toward the top of the giant branch.

The figure also shows another class of variables on the horizontal branch (at g'-i' around 0.2).  These stars, known as RR Lyrae stars, pulsate with short periods of a day or less, so that our observations randomly sampled their pulsation cycles.  The ease with which our sampling reveals their variability demonstrates the power of multi-epoch photometry, and it made us realize that we could use existing multi-epoch surveys to study pulsations in red giants in the LMC and SMC.  The Spitzer Space Telescope surveyed these two galaxies multiple times, and the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) has mapped them several more times and is still adding an additional epoch every six months.

This NSF project enabled us to use multi-epoch photometry to add to the infrared spectra we obtained with Spitzer (in independently funded projects) to study mass loss and dust formation in evolved stars in the LMC and SMC.  Both galaxies have been surveyed extensively in the optical to search for variable stars, but stars in their final evolutionary moments are deeply embedded in their own dust and are invisible at those wavelengths.  Little was known about the pulsations for many of our most evolved spectroscopic targets, but the infrared photometry from Spitzer and WISE solved that problem.

Figure 2 shows that the pulsation amplitude of the stars increases as they get redder, peaks, and then, for the most evolved and dust-enshrouded stars, actually falls.  These deeply embedded stars with reduced pulsations appear to have reached the end of their lives and already ejected nearly all of the envelopes into space.  The power of multi-epoch photometry as revealed by this NSF project has led us to successfully apply for Warm Spitzer time to completely survey the SMC two more times in the infrared in 2017.

This project also focused on ALMA observations.  While we were preparing to select ALMA targets in M5 and M15, we obtained time to observe red giants in another globular cluster, 47 Tuc, with surprising results.  Our plan was to measure outflow velocities with CO lines, but we were unable to detect them in the stars we observed.  In a closely packed environment like 47 Tuc, a single hot white dwarf can dissociate CO molecules around most red giants in the cluster.

We also obtained ALMA time to detect CO in several bright red giants in the LMC.  Comparing to similar stars in the Galaxy reveals that the LMC stars are ejecting gas at slower speeds.  These results are evidence that stars with lower abundances of heavy elements are ejecting mass less efficiently.  This important finding needs to be confirmed with larger samples.

In conclusion, this project has capitalized on the power of multi-epoch photometry to characterize the pulsations of stars in their final evolutionary stages and better understand what we have learned with other techniques, like infrared spectroscopy and radio spectroscopy with ALMA.  The ALMA observations have already proven their value, but it is important to confirm our initial findings with larger samples.  This project has paved the way to use both multi-epoch photometry and ALMA to further probe the question of how stars in more primitive galaxies die and simultaneously enrich their
environments with heavy elements.
